@Richard: As far as French cheeses go, Charles De Gaulle famously said:

Richard,

I think you'd be interested to know that the Tour de France is not only professional, it's the largest sporting event in the world by spectator attendance, at 12-15 MILLION spectators. Compared to the largest in the US, which is the Indianapolis 500, at 500,000 spectators. And why do you consider cycling "effete" when it is likely the most grueling and tactical of the endurance sports? Why do you feel the need to belittle a legitimate professional sport just because it isn't the sport you choose to watch?

Imagine how we're going to feel about the postal system when it costs us $160 billion plus the cost of stamps to maintain that dinosaur, not just $16 billion. But they may have a point that Americans somehow feel validated when one of our own wins at something other than American football, and at an effete sport played out on the intermediate and high mountain ranges of a country that over-taxes its citizens (or those who haven't yet moved away to avoid the taxes), makes passable cheese and wine but over-indulges in goose liver and frogs' legs. Oh, and that doesn't like us much, and couldn't get it right in Vietnam OR Mali.

You should stop looking for morals in Lance Armstrong's story. There actually are two: 1) the notion of truly amateur anything these days that requires an unsullied bloodstream is as foolish as it is completely divorced from reality; and 2) when Oprah needs something splashy to get back on top, that something will always present itself.

Lance Armstrong's story isn't sad: it's merely very human; more so for the monumental conceit required to think that anybody really cares, or even, mostly, notices.

The problem is that while individuals may believe they have paid for them with payroll deductions, they have not in fact done so.  Your payroll taxes have been spent on current recipients, and there is nothing saved for you.  This isn't exactly the government's fault; there's really no place the government can save that kind of money (any bank they deposited it in would fail the moment they began withdrawing).  But the problem with a dedicated tax for something is that it falsely leads people to believe that money has been allocated for that purpose.  It hasn't; and the government does us a great disservice via the fictions of the "trust funds" in indicating that money has been set aside.  If future borrowing and future taxes cannot pay for future benefits, then those benefits cannot be paid, no matter how popular they are.
The B2 is a carbon fiber aircraft.

These problems seem minor compared to the real danger inherent in carbon fiber airplanes.  The material is brittle and susceptible to charing due to lightning strike.  When the tail fell off an Airbus over Long Island, the manufacturer said the pilot pressed too hard on the rudder pedal!  Of course no plane deserves certification if it's even possible to press too hard on a pedal.

I agree, fundamentally, with making college free here, but only for qualified students, and ONLY if they actually, physically, attend classes. As a semi-retired adult auditing a class in the fall of 2012, I was appalled at the number of undergraduates who rarely attended class, even though the professor was required to take attendance and students were penalized on their grade for skipping class. And don't even consider subsidizing on-line education. Everyone involved knows that a huge number of on-line classes involve getting someone else to take your tests. Recently the father of a young man I taught bragged to me that the son paid someone else to take his on-line final exam, since he really didn't need to learn biology for his chosen career. A friend who works for the on-line (and very lucrative) option of a small independent college tells me that more than half their "students" are imposters who enroll just to cash the student-assistance checks. You can do this for two consecutive semesters before being eliminated from the program.
PS - I'm a liberal who has taught in public school for more than 41 years.

If the quality of Chinese exported products is the reason their exporting power is nothing to be concerned about then I think you have not looked much at high scale products... or their creators. Also, ss the overwhelming amount of Chinese students in higher educational institutions in the U.S. not enough of a good indicator for the time being?
On the other note, I agree that college education (and vocational education as well I'd say) ought to be as affordable for everyone as possible. As a penny-pinching international undergraduate student in America, in my day dream I still wish I added 10 years of German or French along with all those effort to learn English.
I major in food science. I think the food field is as big, as diverse, and as important as any field can be, especially in the U.S. Yet 65% of the students (undergraduates and master) are international, coming from not only China but also Indonesia, Malaysia, The Philippines, Vietnam, etc.

You have to wonder about the quality of the education.  If the quality of Chinese education is anything like their exported products, we have nothing to be concerned about !  On the other hand, a 4 year accredited College education in the US ought to be free for any qualified person.  If Bermuda can do it ( isn't that the place where Corporate America and the 1% offshore their money?), then we ought to do it.

Richard, I agree with what you say, especially the way in which the Chinese are taught, but would like to add one point:  Whatever method is currently in use, that will not stifle their desire to learn nor make them complacent.  They will take whatever action is necessary to gain the knowledge they need in spite of the method.  Thus, they are catching up very fast and will surpass the US in the near, not the distant, future which may not be a bad thing.  In order to survive Americans must end their complacency.

The last two sentences of the first paragraph are true; the rest is misleading or irrelevant.

The true part illustrates how quickly the Chinese intend to learn from the rest of the world. No other country (except possibly Singapore) has expanded education, and especially higher education, more quickly. This has created a temporary glut of graduates competing for white collar jobs. Since the economy is expanding so rapidly, there will be an ample trained labor supply to draw from in the future. In terms of the macro-economy, that's a lot better problem to have than the opposite.

Correct! During the cultural revolution (where they burned books, purged intellectuals), instead of going to school, students were forced to do farm labor in the countryside. Decades later, you end up with few qualified professors and even lesser qualified anti-intellectual party leaders.

My mother grew up in China during the cultural revolution and does not trust any doctor who earned their "degree" in the 70s/80s, fearing that they were fraudulently handed out to political favorites instead of academically competent individuals.

On a related note, anyone seeking Chinese Medicine practitioners, do your research and see which university and YEAR they earned their diploma. Make sure the doctors were truly trained, and did not buy their diploma with political loyalty.

Don't sing the praises of Chinese higher education or feel threatened too soon. It will be many years before China can move away from its testing-oriented system and offer a truly world-class higher education. Most Chinese students believe, rightfully, that the US offers top-quality education. No wonder so many study here.

Education in China is still recovering from the crippling of the universities during the cultural revolution. One result of that is only 30% of college faculty there have postgraduate degrees.

We'll see if our right wing conservatives will finally give up this idea of "liberal elitism". And finally agree to fund more universities and education instead of giving away billions of dollars in corporate welfare.

Mali is not a democratic nation.  Its leaders got there through a military coup.

True to type, you start by voicing humanitarian concerns, and then switch to the REAL motive for countries like the US to get involved in desaters such as this: expanding and securing our economic and world power interests.
You have apparently drunk the CoolAid ... And are not even aware of it.

Your point is well-taken- however, Mali is 90% Muslim.  It's true that the majority of Christians live in the South- however, there as throughout the rest of the country, the vast majority of the population identifies as Muslim.  That said, West African Islam is its own bird- moderate, adaptive to local custom.  Certainly not the hard-line extremism the invaders want to impose.  Also, Mali has impressive gold reserves but is nothing like Nigeria or Congo in terms of natural resources, which is why its been left to its own devices until now, for the most part.

The humanitarian disaster of allowing a Taliban type regime to invade a predominately Animist and Christian south would be unheard of. This is not Afghanistan. The locals are not predominantly fundamentalist, and they have already betrayed the Taureg natives in north Mali. They are destroying the mosques of Timbuktu, site of the University of Sankore, once the worlds center of learning.

Africa is rich in resources, and rich in humanitarian disaster. Helping strengthen legitimate regimes, while quelling crimes against humanity serves US and African interests. The natural resources are great, and are being dominated by Chinese. If we can reward and strengthen, democratic nations, like Botswana, Mali, the Africans benefit from stable development, and we benefit from access to the natural resources contained within their nations.

There is no need to involve large deployments of ground troops. Drones and special forces are sufficient, and this is not like Afganistan: these are foreign invaders not locals.

I used to be a kind of scientist, in academia and in the real world. I liked it but it is mostly boring stuff not suitable for creating celebrities of any kind.

Most of scientists are also not very good looking. At 78 I am, as you can see, terribly looking but it had not been much better when I was 40. Definitely not a celebrity material.

Hollywood is still a place where celebrities are made.

Lance is no different from the politicians, the banksters, the hedge fund operators, the oil execs,big health execs (health insurance, pharma, hospital execs) or the NRA.

Egomaniacs who only care about themselves and commit any crime to further themselves..

No more media attention for these, please.except to report their punishment when caught .

Good points.  When was the last time you heard about an astronaut, or a famous heart surgeon, or renowned scientist or architect?  When I was growing up in the 60s and 70s names like DeBakey, Sagan, Jane Goodall, Neal Armstrong etc. were as well-known as those of sports stars and actors.  Maybe I just don't read the right newspapers or magazines but it seems that pop culture and even feature journalism now is solely focused on sports and the "baby bumps" of spurious celebrities.  Very odd.

Lance is an egomaniac that has the highest opinion of himself and no one around him. He thought and still thinks that he can make the rules, any rules, and that the world revolves around him. In all of these characteristics he is not unlike many other celebrities, be it in sports or movies. If there is a lesson for me it is that we need to stop adulating these folks and shift our attention to scientists who send spacecrafts to Jupiter, Saturn and beyond. We need to recognize the teacher in some poor county who motivated a child to go to college and discover a new wonder drug. We need to celebrate the folks at the CDC who track a flu epidemic. Stop this mad rush to put Hollywood stars and sportsmen/women on a pedestal - yes, they have achieved a lot, but so have many others in many other fields of endeavor.
